Fitzpatrick supports
Univ. health program
By ANDREW LASHLEY
Dean of Students Robert
Fitzpatrick voiced his hopes for a
comprehensive University Health
Program at Friday's meeting of
the HAC-sponsored Health
Service study group.
"Ultimately what I'd like to see
is a comprehensive University
Health Plan for students, faculty,
and staff, and dependents. This
long range plan might be
something the committee could

recommend," stated Fitzpatrick.
Fitzpatrick characterized the
study groups' function as a
mandate to review the Health
Service, indicate its problems,
and recommend changes.
,Fitzpatrick added that the
group's purpose was not that of a
trial for the Service.
"To the degree that this
becomes a vigilante committee,
this group's validity could be
jeopardized. This is not a witch
hunt," Fitzpatrick remarked.
Among presently recognizable
problems with the Service,
Fitzpatrick listed budget
deficiencies, staff difficulties, and
the Brown Infirmary's ambiguous
position in the larger University
Health Service, centered in East
Baltimore. According to
Fitzpatrick, the Brown
Infirmary's budget of around
$1 00,000 per year is barely
adequate to cover its present
diagnostic and care services.
Staff difficulties stem from the
uninteresting nature of most
student ailments, which do little
to attract competent doctors, he
said. "We have difficulty
attracting general practitioners
since most student's health
problems are routine, not out of
the ordinary." Fitzpatrick noted.

Frats optimistic as rush begins final week
By JERRY NESER
According to John Gibson,
President of the Council of
Intra-Fraternity Affairs (CIA),
Hopkins Fraternities are doing
rather well this year as the last
week of Freshman Rush begins.
"But we don't want, to count
our eggs too soon," said Rob
Slaymaker, President of Beta
Theta Phi Fraternity. "We will
take as many as we can this year,
but we'll definitely know the
number by the end of this
week," he explained.
Rush, name for the series of
parties and other events initiating
Freshmen into Frat life, will
Officially end this Saturday,
-February 24, when all interested
Freshman are required to register
with the CIA and list their first
three Fraternity preferences
between the hours of 10:00 am
and 12:00 am in Levering Hall.
"The way that Pledge
Saturday works in that each
Fraternity makes up a final list of
pledges and submits it to me at
the end of the week," said
Gibson. "We'll match those
people whom a particular
fraternity wants with the
Freshman's prefered choices," he
asserted.
The registration fee of $5
collected on Pledge Saturday will
be used to sponsor a
CIA social
event for all new pledges, said
Gibson.
According to a member of
Delta Phi Fraternity, Rush is
going particulary well at this
house.
"N'V 're more than happy with
the response thus far,
but at this

point in rush it's too easy to be
overconfident," he said.
John Reefer, President of
Sigma Nu, said "Rush is going
pretty well. So far we have two
girls and about four boy
affiliates."
Tau Epsilor Phi (TEP), largest
of the Homewood Houses,
expects to have about 35 pledges
this year, according to Mike
Kestigian, Chancellor.
"We're very pleased with the
different types of people who
expressed interest this year,"
Kestigan said. "Last year it was a
pretty homogenous group," he
added.
Dwight Kessler, President Of
Delta Upsilon said that the
Freshmen were more responsive
than he had expected. "Right
now we're concentrating on a
couple of key names," he
asserted.

A lot of things go into the making ot a university.
There are students, buildings, green lawns, trees, athletic fields, gymnasiums, classrooms, textbooks, libraries
and, from time to time, faculty members. All of these
things .are the visible signs that a community may exist
here, for the purpose of gaining and imparting knowledge. There must exist too, a sense of trust and a basic
sense of honesty, that what one is told, is the truth,
that what one sees, is what is usually there.
This University and its related Hospital, will start a
$200 million capital campaign Thursday, in honor of
the 100th birthday of the Hopkins institutions. The
opening promises to be a major event with dignitaries
including Governor Mandel\invited and expected from
all over the state and perhaps, the nation.
For the occasion, the coffee shop in Gilman Hall,site
of a reception Thursday, has been closed down for the
week, and the graffiti in the Hutzler Room bathroom
has been painted over, but the Admissions Office has
flopped miserably in its efforts to diversify the student
body. Security on campus continues to be a joke and
Hopkins' most distinguished faculty members continue
to leave. Even John Barth, the biggest faculty catch
lately, will go on a year's leave after first semester next
year. But instead of doing anything about real problems, Hopkins' response is to shove aside, temporarily,
anything that might offend potential donors. It's a
funny way to celebrate a birthday.

Letters to the Editors
To the Editors:
It has come to the attention of this
writer that Vice-President George Benton
has been honored for four consecutive
weeks with the News-Letter "Man of the
Week" award. This unspeakable
achievement came to light while I was
cutting out the now familiar smile of Dr.
Chester Wickwire to add to my collection
of Wickwire memorabilia that already
blankets the walls of my study. (All I
need -now are a few more letters from
"Tricky Dick" Oles, written with that
mordant wit that has sent East Coast
Elitists fleeing to the refuge of their
Massachusetts mothers, to make my
collection of the -Great Names of Johns
Hopkins" complete.)
Your recognition of Vice-President
Benton has been well deserved. Those
who criticize your judgment on the
grounds that Benton has done nothing for
this school are out of order. They forget
*rat Bentkmis slcilltul manipulation of tile
//hr.

more lights to the campus would not cut
down on the number of rapes committed

To the Editors:
I wish to commend Mr. Robert Paulus
on his handling of a difficult subject in
the News-Letter on 2 February 1973
under the title "Animal group attacks
Hopkins' Professor Ray." However, I
wish to clear up some points. First, the
Marine Mammal Council comprises a
' group of scientists which is housed in but
not part of, the National Museum of
Natural History, Smithsonian Institution.
The Council was formed a couple of years
ago for the purpose of writing an
integrated research proposal as a part of
the International Biological Program. I
am the Program Director and the
proposal went before the National
Science Foundation last fall from The
Johns Hopkins University.
Secondly, the appointments to the
Marine Mammal Commission to be made
by President Nixon are to be drawn from,
a list of six, not five names. The Marine
Mammal Protection Act of 1972 created
a moratorium on all activities with regard
to wild marine mammals, including
research, as of December 22, 1972. It is
regrettable that President Nixon has to
date no appointed the Commission and so
there is no permanent guideline for
marine mammal conservation at present,
only interim agreements which have been
published in the Federal Register.

I was quoted correctly in saying that
management is a basic conservation
practice. Management includes protection
and,. environmental matters which insure
that habitats remain healthy. It is also
true .that some managers are involved in
the regulation of exploitation. However,
-protectionist" conservationists have
stated that they are opposed to
management, thinking it wholly an
arrogant, unexploitive matter. I am .not
particularly disturbed about this as it is
only a matter of education before the
term "management" becomes more clear
to them; that, in fact, wildlife
management is what also saved the snowy
egret and whooping crane. It is significant
that the extremist protectionists never
were joined in the battles in Congress last
year with regard to marine mammals by
most conservation groups. Whereas the
Fund for Animals and Friends of Animals
oppose a management bill as "weak", we
opposed a protectionist bill also as
"weak". I do not want to belabor this
point, but ort\y wish to point out that the
(a
professional socitty) were also opposed

I think the major "hang-up" is that
protection considers only the harassment
and killing of animals whereas
management concerns the entire suite of
environmental and population problems
that beset all living things. The latter is a
sophisticated and complex approach,
difficult to sell as we all know.
Once again, my compliments to the
News-Letter and to Mr. Paulus for his
treatment of this difficult subject.

150 minutes with a very rich Olivier and Caine a
By MARK CRISPINMILLER
Andrew Wyke (Laurence Olivier) is
very rich and as British as can be. His
riches and his Britishness are
interdependent, for his many detective
novels, each of them describing some
investigative victory won by the brilliant
and aristocratic St. John Lord Merridewe.
have all been tremendous successes over
the years. Wyke's hero is the child of his
quirky. bright and snobbish imagination.

Wyke's crazy, will-bred prose. the British
ideal that Wyke believes in and tries to
live up to. The aging writer inhabits a
mansion stuffed with gimmicks an('
games.
Into this bastion of charming and

bigoted fantasy comes Milo Tyndal (ne
Tindolini, played by Michael Caine). a
flashy climber who is involved with
Wyke's wife. Tyndal is all cuffs., buttons,
pocket-kerchief and fashionably long
hair. He represents a class of
newly-monied swingers that Wyke finds
repulsive, and yet in his very new-looking
blazer he seems stiff and inhibited in a
way that Wyke, the conservative bear,
could never be. Wyke has summoned Milo

to his estate in order (he claims) to allow
the suave stud to take his wife off his
hands. Why? Because "she converses like
a child of six, and makes love like an
extinct shellfish..!"
So much for exposition. The rest of
Sleuth is a series of surprises and

deceptions that must be seen and
appreciated by everyone who enjoys good
comedy, good mystery, skillful direction
and unexcelled acting. Joseph L.
Mankiewicz has filmed Anthony Shaffer's
Broadway hit with a fine, understated
attentiveness to Olivier, Caine, and the
engaging knickknacks that crowd Wyke's
baronial dwelling. Sleuth stays in and
around the house for almost 150 minutes,
but thanks to Mankiewicz's intelligent
treatment of his material, a slow moment
never occurs. Shaffer's dialogue is
generally hilarious, and MankieiNicz never
attempts forcing it into the background
with distracting visual tricks. His camera
very subtly highlights and compliments
the dramatic action, and "sees" with a
great deal of wit-notice, for example, the
allusion to Hitchcock (a director whose
films are certainly appropriate to the
mystery genre) in the shot of Milo's hand
trailing up a bannister.
Come To Life
Few people would deny that Laurence
Olivier is the greatest actor in the world,
fewer will deny it after seeing Sleuth.
Wyke is a hammy, playful egotist
throughout most of the film, and Olivier
animates the character with countless
gestures. smirks. grimaces, jigs, and of
course his magnificient voice, breaking
out into different dialects, filling the
slightest casual expression with endless
life. Michael Caine has always been a
good actor. but Carter, Palmer, and Alfie
have demanded little more than deadpan
equanimity and a good sense of timing. In
Olivier's company, and with Shaffer's
screenplay, Caine really comes to life.
As if these two performances weren't
enough, the introduction of Alec
Cawthorne as Inspector Doppler only

further improves the cast. It's surprising
that an unknown actor should deliver
such a magnetic performance. I hope he
doesn't disappear after Sleuth leaves the
theaters.
Although Sleuth hasn't been
nominated for an Academy Award, its
director and principal actor all have.
Caine and Olivier are competing with
each other and with Marlon Brando,who as

grizzled, majestic Don Corleone will
probably take the prize. It hardly
matters, because three such actors are so
obviously and equally deserving of
whatever Hollywood has to hand out that
the cnoice of any one is mere formality.
Sleuth is worth, seeing more than once.
Even after its(outcome is familiar and its
"mysteries" solved, it has much to see
and admire.

Day care center need seen as vital
Plans for a proposed expanded
Homewood day care service for
young children are gaining
moment urn, according to
Charlotte Walters and Barbara
Hill, who are coordinating the
effort for the proposed center.
The proposed center would
supplement the Graduate Wives'
Association's_ Cooperative
Nursery, presently located in the
ROTC Building, the gray edifice
to the north of the Newton H.
White Athletic Center.
Sandy Green, President of the
Nursery, stated that the Nursery
handles about twenty children
daily.
Coop
Walters and Hill explained that
there is considerable need on
campus for an expanded day-care
center, which they envision as a

cooperative.
Walters, who is married to a
History professor here, stated
that she and Hill are requesting
names of children who might use
the expanded service, which will
operate up to 40 hours weekly.
The service would be open to
children of faculty, students, and
staff members on a first-come.
first-serve basis. Hill remarked.
No Fed Aid
Walters and Hill have been
investigating possible federal
funding, they reported, but
Government funds are not
considered likely, as most of the
proposed center's users would
come from families not below
the poverty line, as defined by
proposed government guidelines.
Maryland laws and regulations
are considerably more stringent

with respect to day care centers
than with nurseries, such as the
nursery operating in the ROTC
building, the organizers noted.
Because of increased costs for the
proposed center. Walters and Hill
are seeking University funding
from the office of Robert J.
Fitzpatrick, Dean of Students:
"Any financial help we receive
from the , University will be
proportional to the community's
need for the day care 'service.—
Hill reported.
Need Questioned
Though at least one observer
questioned the need for increased
day facilities in the Homewood
Walters and Ilill pointed to
the two other day care facilities
in the Greater Homewood area.
Waiting lists run long at both the
Homewood Friends' Center, on

Present Nursery home, the ROTC Building
the 3200 block of North Charles,
and the Waverly center. The
names of forty children are on
the waiting list at Waverly, the
organizers said.

Gagers win final home game, but miss play-offs
The JHU basketball team won
its final two home games of the
season, beating Western Maryland
on Saturday, 66-61, and
whipping Franklin and Marshall,
70-62, last night.
Unfortunately, the importance
of both contests was negated late
Saturday when Muhlenberg, the

team directly ahead of Hopkins
in the standings upset Widener on
the losers' court, thereby
eliminating the Jays from the
conference playoff race.
In the Western Maryland
match, the small weekend crowd
was treated to an outstanding
shooting exhibition by Paul

Spence, who came off the bench
to lead Hopkins scorers with 20
points. Billy Jews was close
behind with 19 points, his 16th
of which broke the school's
single season scoring record set
last year by Gary Handelman.
Greg DeLong and Chuck LaBerge
were the other Blue Jays in
double figures with 13 and 10
respectively.
Western Maryland had only
two players with over 9 points, a
problem that has plagued them
all year. Dave Cole, a bulky
forward with an excellent shot,
lead all scorers with 21 markers.
Center Dan Stubbs was next with
17 points.
Against the Green Terrors,
JHU built a quick • 13-4 lead
behind 5 points by DeLong and 6
by LaBerge. The visitors cut it to
three at 19-16 before Spence
went into his long distance act.
After a tip-in by Jews made it
21-16, Spence canned a 25
footer, his first shot of the game.
After WMC retaliated, Spence hit

another one from the same
distance, then stole the ball and
tallied on a beautiful driving
layup to make it 27-18.
The next time down the court,
Spence drilled a 20 footer, and,
after another steal, hit one from
the corner to make him 5-5 in
less than 3 minutes. By this time
the score was 31-18 and the hosts
were never threatened
afterwards. The Terrors could
only close the margin at the end
after the issue had been decided.
In the game against F & M. the
Jays won their 12th decisions in
22 starts. The victory, believe it
or not, broke the school record
for most wins in a season. This
time, Bill Jews was the hero for
JHU. The 6-7 junior scored 28
points, 16 in the first half, in
what was probably his finest
performance at home this year.
Jews was particularly tough
inside, scoring most of his points
from where he dared not venture
during most of the season.
Greg DeLong was next in line

NEWS-LETTB1

with 14 points and Bob
Freedman tallied 11. Bill Brooks
led the Diplomats with 18
markers, many coming from off
the visitors' classy fast break.
Ron Valentine and John Huff
each added 14 for the losers.
Hopkins led most of the way
though F & M staged periodic
rallies during the first half. The
Dips led 37-36 with 10 seconds
left in the half but Spence and
DeLong tallied before the buzzer
to give the Hoppies a 40-37 lead.
F & M's last lead was 54-53
midway through the final period
but Jews, Freedman, and Doug
Campbell led the Jays to safety.
Billy scored on a layup, Campbell
dropped an 18 footer, his first
shot of the game, and Freedman
banked one from the comer.
After Bart Callahan hit two free
throws for the Diplomats, John
Rutter sank a short jumper, Jews
went over two opponents for a
tip -in, and Freedman scored
again from the outside to give
Hopkins it biggest lead.

Frats optimistic as rush begins final week
By JERRY NESER
According to John Gibson,
President of the Council of
Intra-Fraternity Affairs (CIA),
Hopkins Fraternities are doing
rather well this year as the last
week of Freshman Rush begins.
"But we don't want, to count
our eggs too soon," said Rob
Slaymaker, President of Beta
Theta Phi Fraternity. "We will
take as many as we can this year,
but we'll definitely know the
number by the end of this
week," he explained.
Rush, name for the series of
parties and other events initiating
Freshmen into Frat life, will
Officially end this Saturday,
-February 24, when all interested
Freshman are required to register
with the CIA and list their first
three Fraternity preferences
between the hours of 10:00 am
and 12:00 am in Levering Hall.
"The way that Pledge
Saturday works in that each
Fraternity makes up a final list of
pledges and submits it to me at
the end of the week," said
Gibson. "We'll match those
people whom a particular
fraternity wants with the
Freshman's prefered choices," he
asserted.
The registration fee of $5
collected on Pledge Saturday will
be used to sponsor a
CIA social
event for all new pledges, said
Gibson.
According to a member of
Delta Phi Fraternity, Rush is
going particulary well at this
house.
"N'V 're more than happy with
the response thus far,
but at this

point in rush it's too easy to be
overconfident," he said.
John Reefer, President of
Sigma Nu, said "Rush is going
pretty well. So far we have two
girls and about four boy
affiliates."
Tau Epsilor Phi (TEP), largest
of the Homewood Houses,
expects to have about 35 pledges
this year, according to Mike
Kestigian, Chancellor.
"We're very pleased with the
different types of people who
expressed interest this year,"
Kestigan said. "Last year it was a
pretty homogenous group," he
added.
Dwight Kessler, President Of
Delta Upsilon said that the
Freshmen were more responsive
than he had expected. "Right
now we're concentrating on a
couple of key names," he
asserted.

A lot of things go into the making ot a university.
There are students, buildings, green lawns, trees, athletic fields, gymnasiums, classrooms, textbooks, libraries
and, from time to time, faculty members. All of these
things .are the visible signs that a community may exist
here, for the purpose of gaining and imparting knowledge. There must exist too, a sense of trust and a basic
sense of honesty, that what one is told, is the truth,
that what one sees, is what is usually there.
This University and its related Hospital, will start a
$200 million capital campaign Thursday, in honor of
the 100th birthday of the Hopkins institutions. The
opening promises to be a major event with dignitaries
including Governor Mandel\invited and expected from
all over the state and perhaps, the nation.
For the occasion, the coffee shop in Gilman Hall,site
of a reception Thursday, has been closed down for the
week, and the graffiti in the Hutzler Room bathroom
has been painted over, but the Admissions Office has
flopped miserably in its efforts to diversify the student
body. Security on campus continues to be a joke and
Hopkins' most distinguished faculty members continue
to leave. Even John Barth, the biggest faculty catch
lately, will go on a year's leave after first semester next
year. But instead of doing anything about real problems, Hopkins' response is to shove aside, temporarily,
anything that might offend potential donors. It's a
funny way to celebrate a birthday.

To the Editors:
I wish to commend Mr. Robert Paulus
on his handling of a difficult subject in
the News-Letter on 2 February 1973
under the title "Animal group attacks
Hopkins' Professor Ray." However, I
wish to clear up some points. First, the
Marine Mammal Council comprises a
' group of scientists which is housed in but
not part of, the National Museum of
Natural History, Smithsonian Institution.
The Council was formed a couple of years
ago for the purpose of writing an
integrated research proposal as a part of
the International Biological Program. I
am the Program Director and the
proposal went before the National
Science Foundation last fall from The
Johns Hopkins University.
Secondly, the appointments to the
Marine Mammal Commission to be made
by President Nixon are to be drawn from,
a list of six, not five names. The Marine
Mammal Protection Act of 1972 created
a moratorium on all activities with regard
to wild marine mammals, including
research, as of December 22, 1972. It is
regrettable that President Nixon has to
date no appointed the Commission and so
there is no permanent guideline for
marine mammal conservation at present,
only interim agreements which have been
published in the Federal Register.

I was quoted correctly in saying that
management is a basic conservation
practice. Management includes protection
and,. environmental matters which insure
that habitats remain healthy. It is also
true .that some managers are involved in
the regulation of exploitation. However,
-protectionist" conservationists have
stated that they are opposed to
management, thinking it wholly an
arrogant, unexploitive matter. I am .not
particularly disturbed about this as it is
only a matter of education before the
term "management" becomes more clear
to them; that, in fact, wildlife
management is what also saved the snowy
egret and whooping crane. It is significant
that the extremist protectionists never
were joined in the battles in Congress last
year with regard to marine mammals by
most conservation groups. Whereas the
Fund for Animals and Friends of Animals
oppose a management bill as "weak", we
opposed a protectionist bill also as
"weak". I do not want to belabor this
point, but ort\y wish to point out that the
(a
professional socitty) were also opposed

I think the major "hang-up" is that
protection considers only the harassment
and killing of animals whereas
management concerns the entire suite of
environmental and population problems
that beset all living things. The latter is a
sophisticated and complex approach,
difficult to sell as we all know.
Once again, my compliments to the
News-Letter and to Mr. Paulus for his
treatment of this difficult subject.

150 minutes with a very rich Olivier and Caine a
By MARK CRISPINMILLER
Andrew Wyke (Laurence Olivier) is
very rich and as British as can be. His
riches and his Britishness are
interdependent, for his many detective
novels, each of them describing some
investigative victory won by the brilliant
and aristocratic St. John Lord Merridewe.
have all been tremendous successes over
the years. Wyke's hero is the child of his
quirky. bright and snobbish imagination.

Wyke's crazy, will-bred prose. the British
ideal that Wyke believes in and tries to
live up to. The aging writer inhabits a
mansion stuffed with gimmicks an('
games.
Into this bastion of charming and

bigoted fantasy comes Milo Tyndal (ne
Tindolini, played by Michael Caine). a
flashy climber who is involved with
Wyke's wife. Tyndal is all cuffs., buttons,
pocket-kerchief and fashionably long
hair. He represents a class of
newly-monied swingers that Wyke finds
repulsive, and yet in his very new-looking
blazer he seems stiff and inhibited in a
way that Wyke, the conservative bear,
could never be. Wyke has summoned Milo

to his estate in order (he claims) to allow
the suave stud to take his wife off his
hands. Why? Because "she converses like
a child of six, and makes love like an
extinct shellfish..!"
So much for exposition. The rest of
Sleuth is a series of surprises and

deceptions that must be seen and
appreciated by everyone who enjoys good
comedy, good mystery, skillful direction
and unexcelled acting. Joseph L.
Mankiewicz has filmed Anthony Shaffer's
Broadway hit with a fine, understated
attentiveness to Olivier, Caine, and the
engaging knickknacks that crowd Wyke's
baronial dwelling. Sleuth stays in and
around the house for almost 150 minutes,
but thanks to Mankiewicz's intelligent
treatment of his material, a slow moment
never occurs. Shaffer's dialogue is
generally hilarious, and MankieiNicz never
attempts forcing it into the background
with distracting visual tricks. His camera
very subtly highlights and compliments
the dramatic action, and "sees" with a
great deal of wit-notice, for example, the
allusion to Hitchcock (a director whose
films are certainly appropriate to the
mystery genre) in the shot of Milo's hand
trailing up a bannister.
Come To Life
Few people would deny that Laurence
Olivier is the greatest actor in the world,
fewer will deny it after seeing Sleuth.
Wyke is a hammy, playful egotist
throughout most of the film, and Olivier
animates the character with countless
gestures. smirks. grimaces, jigs, and of
course his magnificient voice, breaking
out into different dialects, filling the
slightest casual expression with endless
life. Michael Caine has always been a
good actor. but Carter, Palmer, and Alfie
have demanded little more than deadpan
equanimity and a good sense of timing. In
Olivier's company, and with Shaffer's
screenplay, Caine really comes to life.
As if these two performances weren't
enough, the introduction of Alec
Cawthorne as Inspector Doppler only

further improves the cast. It's surprising
that an unknown actor should deliver
such a magnetic performance. I hope he
doesn't disappear after Sleuth leaves the
theaters.
Although Sleuth hasn't been
nominated for an Academy Award, its
director and principal actor all have.
Caine and Olivier are competing with
each other and with Marlon Brando,who as

grizzled, majestic Don Corleone will
probably take the prize. It hardly
matters, because three such actors are so
obviously and equally deserving of
whatever Hollywood has to hand out that
the cnoice of any one is mere formality.
Sleuth is worth, seeing more than once.
Even after its(outcome is familiar and its
"mysteries" solved, it has much to see
and admire.

Day care center need seen as vital
Plans for a proposed expanded
Homewood day care service for
young children are gaining
moment urn, according to
Charlotte Walters and Barbara
Hill, who are coordinating the
effort for the proposed center.
The proposed center would
supplement the Graduate Wives'
Association's_ Cooperative
Nursery, presently located in the
ROTC Building, the gray edifice
to the north of the Newton H.
White Athletic Center.
Sandy Green, President of the
Nursery, stated that the Nursery
handles about twenty children
daily.
Coop
Walters and Hill explained that
there is considerable need on
campus for an expanded day-care
center, which they envision as a

cooperative.
Walters, who is married to a
History professor here, stated
that she and Hill are requesting
names of children who might use
the expanded service, which will
operate up to 40 hours weekly.
The service would be open to
children of faculty, students, and
staff members on a first-come.
first-serve basis. Hill remarked.
No Fed Aid
Walters and Hill have been
investigating possible federal
funding, they reported, but
Government funds are not
considered likely, as most of the
proposed center's users would
come from families not below
the poverty line, as defined by
proposed government guidelines.
Maryland laws and regulations
are considerably more stringent

with respect to day care centers
than with nurseries, such as the
nursery operating in the ROTC
building, the organizers noted.
Because of increased costs for the
proposed center. Walters and Hill
are seeking University funding
from the office of Robert J.
Fitzpatrick, Dean of Students:
"Any financial help we receive
from the , University will be
proportional to the community's
need for the day care 'service.—
Hill reported.
Need Questioned
Though at least one observer
questioned the need for increased
day facilities in the Homewood
Walters and Ilill pointed to
the two other day care facilities
in the Greater Homewood area.
Waiting lists run long at both the
Homewood Friends' Center, on

Present Nursery home, the ROTC Building
the 3200 block of North Charles,
and the Waverly center. The
names of forty children are on
the waiting list at Waverly, the
organizers said.

Gagers win final home game, but miss play-offs
The JHU basketball team won
its final two home games of the
season, beating Western Maryland
on Saturday, 66-61, and
whipping Franklin and Marshall,
70-62, last night.
Unfortunately, the importance
of both contests was negated late
Saturday when Muhlenberg, the

team directly ahead of Hopkins
in the standings upset Widener on
the losers' court, thereby
eliminating the Jays from the
conference playoff race.
In the Western Maryland
match, the small weekend crowd
was treated to an outstanding
shooting exhibition by Paul

Spence, who came off the bench
to lead Hopkins scorers with 20
points. Billy Jews was close
behind with 19 points, his 16th
of which broke the school's
single season scoring record set
last year by Gary Handelman.
Greg DeLong and Chuck LaBerge
were the other Blue Jays in
double figures with 13 and 10
respectively.
Western Maryland had only
two players with over 9 points, a
problem that has plagued them
all year. Dave Cole, a bulky
forward with an excellent shot,
lead all scorers with 21 markers.
Center Dan Stubbs was next with
17 points.
Against the Green Terrors,
JHU built a quick • 13-4 lead
behind 5 points by DeLong and 6
by LaBerge. The visitors cut it to
three at 19-16 before Spence
went into his long distance act.
After a tip-in by Jews made it
21-16, Spence canned a 25
footer, his first shot of the game.
After WMC retaliated, Spence hit

another one from the same
distance, then stole the ball and
tallied on a beautiful driving
layup to make it 27-18.
The next time down the court,
Spence drilled a 20 footer, and,
after another steal, hit one from
the corner to make him 5-5 in
less than 3 minutes. By this time
the score was 31-18 and the hosts
were never threatened
afterwards. The Terrors could
only close the margin at the end
after the issue had been decided.
In the game against F & M. the
Jays won their 12th decisions in
22 starts. The victory, believe it
or not, broke the school record
for most wins in a season. This
time, Bill Jews was the hero for
JHU. The 6-7 junior scored 28
points, 16 in the first half, in
what was probably his finest
performance at home this year.
Jews was particularly tough
inside, scoring most of his points
from where he dared not venture
during most of the season.
Greg DeLong was next in line

NEWS-LETTB1

with 14 points and Bob
Freedman tallied 11. Bill Brooks
led the Diplomats with 18
markers, many coming from off
the visitors' classy fast break.
Ron Valentine and John Huff
each added 14 for the losers.
Hopkins led most of the way
though F & M staged periodic
rallies during the first half. The
Dips led 37-36 with 10 seconds
left in the half but Spence and
DeLong tallied before the buzzer
to give the Hoppies a 40-37 lead.
F & M's last lead was 54-53
midway through the final period
but Jews, Freedman, and Doug
Campbell led the Jays to safety.
Billy scored on a layup, Campbell
dropped an 18 footer, his first
shot of the game, and Freedman
banked one from the comer.
After Bart Callahan hit two free
throws for the Diplomats, John
Rutter sank a short jumper, Jews
went over two opponents for a
tip -in, and Freedman scored
again from the outside to give
Hopkins it biggest lead.
